Fields.DialogueText: Oh, never, Kanchou. Ogenki desu ka?
I'm fine Kasumi. Are you okay? You seem a bit...vague today.
What gives you that impression?
You seem to be turning the South China Sea into a lake.
Nani!? Oh, no... You're right. I've drawn this coast entirely wrong. Well, damn. I've been working on this since morning.

Fields.MenuText: You still might be able to use this. Who said it had to be a real world map?
There isn't anything more important you could be doing?
It's a fine lake, if it's any consolation.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe I'll send it over to Shigure for a birthday present. I daresay she hasn't lived in the real world since she was commissioned.
Everything's in order, Kanchou. I made sure of that before the sun rose to give me light to draw by.
You can go there if you want. I don't think I could handle somewhere so... enclosed.
Honestly, my first clue was the tea. Or lack thereof. That cup's been dry all day.
A cast iron teapot full of boiling leaf water.
Kami can take it. Did you know that some of us drink oil?
Does it... help?
It certainly doesn't hurt.
@BATTLE
Is now a bad time?
You worry too much, Kanchou. I might just be drinking directly from the pot, for all you know.
*ALARM*
Now, Funayūrei can hurt. But only if we let them.
What's her deal?
How's mapping the world coming?
Is there anything you Belles can't do?
I don't think it's an us thing. If something truly seizes your fancy, you can do just about anything with it. Tadataka spent seventeen years of his life mapping Japan, you know.
The last seventeen years, I think you mentioned.
We're all in search of the one thing we'd be content to die doing.

Fields.MenuText: Could you maybe lighten up a little?
Whatever I'm doing, I'd prefer it didn't kill me.
Have you found it?

Fields.DialogueText: Mā. Sumimasen, Kanchou. That sounded a little less depressing in my head.
What good fortune you have me by your side!
Maybe. But you're not really living your life if you stop looking.
Do you think Renoir found it?
Oh, they weren't uncharted. I charted them.
For your personal use.
Maybe if he'd been honest with us I would have given him the one he needed.
No. But you believed me. That's what's important.
Careful you don't give away all your tricks.
What can I say? You're a disarming sort.
Fortunately, I memorized the charts I gave to our friend Renoir.
Who knows? Even if it meant slipping the authorities, I certainly wouldn't have wanted to drift off into uncharted waters.
Really?
*ALARM*
Besides, it's essential to know what we've got in our arsenal. Especially at times like these. Coming, Kanchou?
Hmm? Yes, Kasumi, of course.
Now who's disarmed?
@BATTLE
Yare yare. I was afraid of this.
Is this what's been bothering you?
The possibility of it. And now the reality. It seems the General Staff have a solution in mind for our porous security.
Sending someone else to find one. We'll be hosting military police observers for this next leg of the tour.
They weren't mentioned specifically by name. Maybe we'll get lucky.

Fields.MenuText: Lucky enough to have Tokyo's eye fixed on us, looking for who knows what.
What do they know that we don't?
The Navy General Staff wouldn't allow it.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll just have to be on our best behavior, won't we?
How to prevent a petty thief from escaping, if they're to be believed.
They know the Army's excesses all too well, Kanchou. But there's only so much they can do to prevent them.
Did they say how long they'd be with us?
Figuratively, and as politely as possible. In a way, that's the loudest kind of yelling.
What's that letter? Higher-ups yelling at us?
What's their solution?
Holy... you don't mean the Kempeitai?
"Until such time as a course of action with intent to reform current practices may be recommended, should such a measure be necessary." In plain Japanese, "whenever."
There's really no weaseling out of this?
Short of faking a sudden outbreak of cholera, no. And that would be more trouble than it's worth.
Looks like we're treading lightly for our guests.
*ALARM*
I suppose an unfortunate accident would reflect even more poorly on us.
Kasumi!
Intrusive thoughts, Kanchou. Pay them no mind.
@BATTLE
And... that's that map fixed. The southern Chinese coast from Hainan to Macao.
We're still calling him that?
How better to remember him than by his deception? Besides, he never did tell us his real name.
Or what he was doing with that Morgana footage. You don't think he was some kind of spy?
He certainly wasn't one of ours. More likely he was in the right place at the right time.

Fields.MenuText: I just wish the General Staff would tell us what they're doing with the footage.
That's our job.
Doing the wrong thing.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm starting to wish we hadn't turned it over. There might have been something we missed...
And I like to think we're making the best of it... even if it requires less than our best.
There's nothing wrong with survival, Kanchou. But we're all in this together. Lose sight of that and you can become just as dangerous as the Funayūrei.
I wouldn't dwell on it, Kasumi. We're the first line of defense. Maybe the only line of defense. You've been standing firm.
You sure it isn't more of a lake?
There's plenty of ocean to swim in if you'd like to find out. Maybe Renoir will tell you.
And you, Kanchou. Maybe that's all the military police escort is concerned with.
It's harder for a Morgana to slip by us than it is for a human.
Set a human to catch a human, right?
I'm human. I like to think I'm the right person for the job.
*ALARM*
You've proven yourself to me. That's what counts.
And you to me. One of these days the admirals will listen to their ships.
@BATTLE
So this is Kasumi.
Welcome aboard. You must be the observer.
Lieutenant Colonel Noritaka Kondo, at your service. IJN General Staff have sent me and my men to assess your vessel's battle readiness... and your relationship to the vessel in question.
Sore wa kōeidesu.
To His Imperial Majesty. The Kami are manifestations of his will.
First and foremost. Even within the Imperial General Headquarters, it's been suggested that you appeared during Japan's hour of greatest need.
Such an occasion must be risen to.
Indeed. At the risk of arrogance, I like to think your kanchou and I serve similar purposes. As do your crew.
If different callings. You're with the Kempeitai, then?
Ha! No, Kanchou, I work for a living. My men and I answer directly to the General Staff. Consider yourselves under our protection from those Army interlopers.

Fields.MenuText: I don't like him.
He'd better stay out of our way.
That went well.

Fields.DialogueText: He certainly likes to keep things cryptic, doesn't he?
He seems conscious of where our jurisdictions begin and end, at least.
Almost too well. I'm having trouble reading him.
That's one theory put to rest, at least. He's not Kempeitai.
*ALARM*
At least we can continue to put our best foot forward.
@BATTLE
So this, too, is Kasumi. Tell me, with whom does your allegiance lie?
I see. Forgive me. The General Staff weren't forthcoming on the details.
I assure you, we are told what we need to be told.
Shall I have one of the crew escort you to your quarters?
Thank you, Kami-sama. I look forward to our partnership.
They're not the only ones bullying their way into other people's business. But they're certainly among the best at it.
I understand you have questions about the footage you and your Kami found.
We'd been over it ourselves. Was the General Staff able to make anything of it we weren't?
That depends on what you made of it.
Indeed. Your performance does you credit, but there is always more to be learned.
I'm actually more curious about who filmed it and why.
That I can answer. We lost some operatives when that prisoner transport convoy was attacked. The Funayūrei footage is a... pet project of our organization.
Military police getting into the film business?
Hello, Kasumi. Kondo and I were just finishing up here.
Ah! Curse my timing. It's better on the battlefield than off.
Nice save.
I'd watch out for him. He may not be Kempeitai, but his organization's cut from the same cloth. Even if that cloth matches our uniforms.
*ALARM*
I can still loosen a guardrail here and there, you know. While we're on the subject of secrets.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It was a rare opportunity to study their movements. We're usually too busy fighting them.
It might be good for a monster movie with some editing.
I doubt it would be of much value. They tend to evolve quicker than you can pin them down.

Fields.DialogueText: I admit to a weakness for the genre. Perhaps when the war is won the archives can be mined.
And yet there is value in tracking their development, however briefly.
When we find filmmakers willing to cooperate. Intelligence comes from the unlikeliest of places.
Your Kami, for example. I understand she's embarking on a grand cartography project to rival Tadataka's work.
I wouldn't go quite that far. I prefer to think of myself as a devoted student.
Doubtless. My men and I are eager to observe.
He definitely knows more than he's letting on. I think he knows we know, too.
What's the world coming to when you form your own secret police to protect you from the other secret police?
Let's not jump to conclusions.
Que pensez-vous des invités?
Everything all right? He looked worried.
One of our French crew. He's gotten some longer looks than he'd like from Kondo and his men.

Fields.MenuText: I'm guessing he's not the only Westerner on our crew who's noticed.
Did any of them approach him?
Nothing like suspicious activity to get you practicing French.

Fields.DialogueText: Zan'nen'nagara. There are at least two British sailors with similar concerns.
Not so far. Language training isn't a priority of theirs, it seems.
The opportunity is welcome, if unfortunate. When you feel surrounded, it helps to have someone to be surrounded with.
Well, let me know if this continues to be a problem. I'll make it Kondo's problem.
*ALARM*
It's bad enough we have the Morganas to worry about. I didn't sign up to protect my crew from their own country.
Unfortunately, the Empire is not the Emperor. Not to hear some of his more zealous servants tell it...
@BATTLE
Si vous me demandez... ils sont dangereux. Le regard qu'ils me donnent...
I think you're right. Let's pick this up later.
If they lay one hand on any of my crew...
You don't think they'd do that, do you?
We all serve the Empire in our own way, Kanchou, and according to a strict code of ethics. But the rules are much looser when it comes to dealing with foreigners.
Even foreigners serving aboard Imperial vessels? Fighting a common enemy?
Especially them. Our house, our rules, as Kondo might put it. Guests in that house are not treated so differently from subordinates.
Room for one more?
Of course. Sit down, Lieutenant Colonel.
Kondo, please. The IJN and the INPF enjoy parallel authority here. There's no reason to stand on ceremony.
Kondo it is. How are you finding Kasumi?
That's Kasumi for you. She's friendly, but she takes time opening up to most people.
I'm sure. She spends so much of her down time drawing.

Fields.MenuText: Get her talking about geography and there's no stopping her. It's pretty fascinating.
She's no slouch in a fight, either. The things I've seen her hit with that uchi-ne...
She's got a great rapport with the crew, too. Being multilingual certainly helps.

Fields.DialogueText: I myself am something of a geography student. A byproduct of my work taking me to all corners of the Empire... old and new.
Even in modern war there is room for tradition.
I suppose it would. Yours is a much more diverse force than mine.
That's a Kami for you. Made in the image of the divine.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Damn. Lunch will have to wait.
You have a rare blessing in being her chosen, Kanchou. I'd advise you guard her against any fell influence.
The ship or the girl?
Yes.
In both cases... agreeable, if reserved.
Jury's still out on that one.
Well, neither of us are theologians. But I call these things like I see them. Part of the job.
Ah! There you are. Was that Kondo back there?
Yeah. Just talking over lunch.
What about?
I have no idea.
All right, now I'm worried.
What's going on?
I've written to three dealers now in search of a copy of Madame Bovary. The film's one of my favorites, and I've been meaning to read the book forever. No response.

Fields.MenuText: You think the Morganas might have intercepted your letters?

Fields.DialogueText: Not thrice in as many weeks. Even they wouldn't be so predictable. And the mail is some of the best protected cargo around.
Has anyone else been getting their mail?
Now that you mention it... yes. I saw some of the crew reading letters from family just the other day.
So unless three separate dealers simply haven't gotten back to you...
... The problem's on my end.
Hmm. Is the government censor overreacting?
I've never had a problem getting foreign literature before.
Before...?
Before the military police presence. I wonder if Kondo might not be the man to pester.
*ALARM*
It does now. We're outside the traditional chain of command. And chains are for rattling, after all.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they're just taking a little longer.
Flaubert's ambitious for someone who's still learning French.

Fields.DialogueText: Military mail is more efficient than that. When was the last time you sent a letter?
I can't help it, Kanchou. See a mountain and I have to climb it. Or map it.
We'll have to tread carefully. His superiors report to the Emperor.
And I report to the Emperor himself. If you want to get technical about it, I outrank both of you.
Does "Kami" count as a rank?
Something I can help you with, Kanchou?
Kasumi had a question, actually. It's to do with the mail.
It's the oddest thing, Kondo. Mine has been repeatedly lost in transit.
Not lost. Held.
... Dōiu imidesu ka?
As you well know, the Kami are under the strictest scrutiny of all when it comes to the military mail censor.
And yet the most leeway with how we spend our time.
Indeed. Perhaps that helps explain why a Western criminal in our possession gave us the slip.
If you think for a second that Kasumi let him get away -
I don't know what I think. Once my men have vetted your correspondence, I'll have a better idea.

Fields.MenuText: You'll release her mail at once.
How long will that take?
Why hers specifically? Why not mine?

Fields.DialogueText: On whose authority? A person of interest?
You can't put a timetable on national security.
I can always flag you for scrutiny.
I am the Emperor's servant! How dare you question my loyalty?
That is exactly what the Emperor's other servants have ordered me to do. Have you never once checked your tools for rust?
She's not a tool. She's a person.
A person who can be sabotaged. Even commandeered. For the good of the Empire, she must be... maintained.
I can maintain myself quite well, thank you very much. I and my crew.
Ah, your crew. I was just getting to them.
*ALARM*
I'll let you do what you do best. If have complaints, I invite you to forward them to the General Staff.
By mail.
The lifeblood of any great country.
@BATTLE
Damn it! We're letting him walk all over us.
Prisoners aboard our own ship. Aboard me.
Well, we're not getting any help from Tokyo. Kondo's men are watching the mail and the radio.
Don't remind me, Kanchou. I can sense them anywhere aboard me. Like bugs crawling around just underneath my clothes.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think any of your sisters are being treated this way?
Can't you just ignore that?
We've got to fight back.

Fields.DialogueText: There's no way of knowing just yet. We're on our own, Kanchou.
The only thing worse than knowing they're there is not knowing.
I'm worried for the crew, Kanchou. Kondo wouldn't be above punishing them for our actions.
We have to come at this carefully, Kanchou.
Well, we're not getting anything done out here.
Maybe you're not. Drawing helps me think.
Kondo can't take the world from us, at least.
Tadataka made his maps so people would know the world better. If you can see it, you can cross it. The Funayūrei would steal the seas from us and undo all his work.
@BATTLE
Kondo's no Funayūrei, Kanchou. But anyone who blinds and deafens us to the world beyond my structure... is just as dangerous as they are.
I'll find a way around them, Kasumi. They can't be everywhere at once.
They're going to try. Be careful, Kanchou.
I can be a little reckless. I've got you on my side.
You've never made a mess I couldn't clean up.
Don't forget we both hosted Renoir.
Aboard your ship.
Thought you outranked me.
*ALARM*
I prefer to think of it as a partnership. Whichever lets me tease you.
There's a few of Kondo's creatures missing from lunch.
They're on a tight watch schedule, Kanchou. They rotate just as we do.
It's a bit of an effort keeping track of so many, but yes. Why?
I think I can get one over on them if you sketch out their movements.
I've actually been doing that in the margins of the charts. They're frustratingly efficient.
Do what you will with them. Just be careful.
I should be telling you that.
Heh. I don't tell you how to do your job.
Kanchou! This is... Madame Bovary?

Fields.MenuText: We can't let him control us.
Maybe we can get a message to one of your sisters.
You and whichever crew you get to help translate.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. No sense letting our enemy be the only one with surprises up their sleeves.
It's more trouble than it's worth to try and control us all.
I feel confident I can tackle this on my own, but I have plenty of friends here just in case.
Now, then, I've still got a report to fill out...
What? What is it, Kasumi?
You know as well as I that our guests conduct their own trials... mete out their own justice. Promise me you'll be careful.
Don't worry, Kasumi. They wouldn't be in their line of work if they didn't think they could push people around. You just have to refuse to be pushed.
Hmm... And you say you know where they all are at any given moment?
Can I see them?
*ALARM*
What's that?
Bringing me peace of mind, of course. Thus far I haven't needed to.
@BATTLE
Package for you. At long last.
I caught one of Kondo's men alone and bullied him into giving it to me. Looks like I guessed correctly.
Arigatō, Kanchou. This will at least keep me sane until Kondo runs his course.
Kanchou, wait.
Busy, Kanchou?
Immensely. We're in the middle of an apocalypse.
So it would seem. Let our guard down for an instant, and we may be taken entirely by surprise.

Fields.MenuText: Even your men must have a break now and again.
So far that hasn't been a problem.
It's that kind of vigilance that will win the war.

Fields.DialogueText: Where possible. But duty can call at any time.
And yet I wonder what it is you are guarding against.
Vigilance begins at home.
I'll be frank, Kanchou: how do you know you can trust your crew?
I'd trust any one of them with my life.
And yet the criminal was able to sneak past them and effect an escape. What was his name... Renoir?
How did you-
People talk, Kanchou. Your crew talk. That is exactly why you need us. Loose lips sink ships, as they say.
The Funayūrei are not our only enemy, as you well know. The Westerners jealously guard their stolen islands. China continues to dig in against the tide of a better future.
If you're looking for traitors, look elsewhere. My crew are fighting for their lives and their countries.
And so am I.
*ALARM*
Keep your conspiracies to yourself. We've got real evil to fight.
Give my regards to the Kami. Whenever she isn't absorbed in that new book of hers.
@BATTLE
See them, Kasumi?
Lurking just beyond the inlet. I've been waiting for them all morning.
That explains the illustrations.
The Funayūrei won't be in that stretch of water forever. But my charts can serve as war records, too.
Qu'est-ce qui se passe? Tu es fou!
Don't give me that nonsense! You've been slacking since we arrived. That shooting proves it!
This gaijin is a traitor, Kanchou! You protect him?
We protect whoever fights for us, Officer.
What's all the noise?
Perhaps not. But malice is easy to disguise as incompetence.
I know my crew, Kondo. This man is one of my best gunners.
My people are here to enforce honesty and good character in the Emperor's name, Kasumi-sama. For your protection.
Then it seems we're at an impasse. I'll decide what I need to be protected from.
I've seen your people breathing down my people's necks, Kondo. Don't think I don't know where this is coming from.
Back to your quarters, Suzuki. There's nothing more to be said here.
@BATTLE
Break it up, both of you! Sailor, back off! You, don't touch my crew.

Fields.MenuText: Enough. This man's done nothing wrong.
Kondo, control your men or I'll control them for you.
Get this jumped-up cadet to the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: Sir, the French gunner came up short of the Funayūrei more than once. Are we going to tolerate his slacking!?
War stokes the mildest of tempers. Can you blame my man for his zeal?
I'll decide how my man is to be dealt with, Kanchou. Parallel authority, remember?
This is getting out of hand. He's testing us.
They know they have the General Staff's imprimatur to act as judge and jury. Using his minions to provoke our people... despicable.
Good thing our crew are levelheaded sorts.
Everyone has a breaking point, Kanchou. That's when you find out what they've been holding back.
I had to shoo one of Kondo's goons away from outside.
Trying to listen in, eh?
It seems they don't know the extent of my senses. I'm content to keep it that way. Tea?
Please. It's all we can do these days to get a moment to ourselves. This is a relief.
I've missed this, too. We can't even steal an evening for a movie for fear of being accused of dereliction.

Fields.MenuText: Belles don't do dereliction.

Fields.DialogueText: What do they even hope to accomplish?
Obedience. It's easy to accept Kami when your culture's familiar with the concept. Harder to accept that they're just as human as anyone else.
Independent, you mean.
No less devoted. Just not in the way they'd like.
It's complicated, Kanchou. Our house, our rules, to oversimplify. Doubly so if you've surrendered. Surrender and you lose your honor... and then our code of honor doesn't apply to you.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It'll have to wait. Ready to go put on another show?
I heard arguing. What's wrong?
Not in principle, but try telling that to the military police. They're the ones who decide the legal definition.

Fields.MenuText: I don't care what they accuse us of. They're not separating us.
Even one in Japanese?

Fields.DialogueText: I... Never, Kanchou. You're stuck with me.
Not of the sort I'd prefer. I don't judge my films by their patriotism.
What's that got to do with the non-Japanese crew?
I suppose there's debate over whether serving aboard a foreign vessel means surrender.
There you have it. The world may be united, but unity is simply not enough for some people.
At least Kondo's man has drifted back this way. Open the door as quickly and sharply as you can.
Men like Kondo seek to dominate. And such men must be dominated. Now, I have a plan...
Soreha... Hai, soreha kinō shimasu.
I've never understood how you can do your work without any equipment.
With rare exceptions, Kami have excellent eyesight. Combine that with a natural sense of distance and you get precision Tadataka could only have imagined.

Fields.MenuText: With the tradeoff being that you can't go inland.

Fields.DialogueText: Some of my sisters are hard at work on a solution. If you can fly, one day we will walk.
Let's see what we've got today. ... Wait, I recognize that alphabet.
You're making this chart in French?
Calligraphy, cartography, and language all in one.
Our guests think they have an Imperial mandate. I am one. It's time I started acting like it.
Can you get away with throwing them overboard?
@BATTLE
They want a Kami. I'll give them one.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Could a human learn to do this?
I think you missed a sandbar.

Fields.DialogueText: Possibly, but you'd need to start even earlier than Tadataka did.
I know I didn't. One of us is capable of swimming out there to prove me correct.
I have to practice somehow.
You're not worried about being seen?
If I could, I would have. Then they'd send another just like Kondo. The General Staff need to see that we serve at the pleasure of the Emperor, not the police.
What do you have in mind?
Bow.
Heh. Merde.
I've learned that one. You'll learn respect.
What the hell!?
Nani!?
Kondo, stand down!
I am exercising my authority as a lieutenant colonel of the naval military police.
You're striking a member of our crew!

Fields.MenuText: Look at yourself. You think people are going to just knuckle under?
Are you insane!? He's writing about the weather!
This is beyond the pale. You're spending the rest of the tour in the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: Everyone has a breaking point. We are tasked with finding it.
If you want to hide sedition, hide it in plain sight.
There is no presumption of innocence in the matter of your disloyalty! I will not let a suspect conduct their own trial.
Enough. It is clear that your command has been compromised. By the authority invested in me by the Emperor and his Naval General Staff-
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I suppose we'll find out. Kanchou, I order you to ready the crew for battle.
*PUNCH*
My men searched this spy's quarters. This is what they found.
It just so happens that our Kami can read French. Kasumi, if you would?
Weather... ship duties... family matters. Kondo... this is a diary.
It would not be the first used to disguise codes and rebellious agendas.
Kanchou, I'm putting you under arrest!
What!?
You may have power of arrest, Kondo. But the kanchou is my prisoner now. I'm sure the General Staff will be happy to clarify the limits of my custody.
Clever, Kami. But the Empire does not run on finders keepers.
Heh. Yes, ma'am.
What!?
Pass me the teapot, won't you, my prisoner?
You are enjoying this entirely too much.
Oh, hush. It got you out of that scrape with Kondo, didn't it?
The gunner, too. I had him take the day off in the infirmary. These MPs are out of control, Kasumi.
Au contraire. They're right where we want them.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want them aboard.
You're starting to scare me, Kasumi.
Frustrated and angry?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank goodness for that. Power is most dangerous when not feared.
It's an unfamiliar sort of feeling, Kanchou.
State-sanctioned divinity?
I suppose it's always been within my authority as a Kami, Kanchou... but never something I'd considered.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
What? Oh, no, not at all. I wasn't expecting to feel... safe.
And they won't be. They'll make that decision themselves.
At their own impotence. They believe there's nothing they can do. They're probably right.
I always viewed our relationship as a partnership.
Which connotes equality. And yet... well, let's not dwell on the implications now. Even a goddess needs to be acknowledged as such.
Oh, come on. Did you see the way those guys were shaking? I bet there's nothing you couldn't get them to do.
It's one thing to be confronted with power. Quite another to believe in it.
What I've always believed - what they've never understood - is this: Real power isn't beating someone into submission. It's making them wish you would.
Is something wrong, Kanchou?
Don't worry. You've got nothing to fear from me.
I came as soon as I heard. What happened?
Kanchou! I have a man half drowned in the infirmary. Care to explain?

Fields.MenuText: How the hell am I supposed to answer for his accident? For that matter, how are you supposed to?

Fields.DialogueText: Convenient... and yet I'm forced to agree.
I'll ask him myself. Tell me what happened.
I... I was interviewing one of your people... An American, I think. She made her excuses and left before I could get a read on her.
And then?
I leaned on the guardrail to take in the air, and... it gave way! Like it wasn't even there. Damned thing was sabotaged or something...
Sabotage indeed. I'll see about getting it repaired in port.
See that you do, Kanchou. Your Kami must be in considerable discomfort.
I am, a little bit. Nothing I can't fix, though.
You had something to do with this, didn't you?
I saw his little interview. I thought the poor woman would faint, the way he was grilling her.
Did he happen to see you?
*ALARM*
Only a little?
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like the infirmary's flooded.
He's your man. You explain.

Fields.DialogueText: Very funny, Kanchou. You know what I mean.
You think I'd be asking for your help if I could?
Why, I was the one who saved him.
Magnanimous of you.
I'm a merciful god. I only hesitated a little in pulling him from the waves.
He'd almost drifted from my manifestation range. I wasn't really paying attention. Don't worry, I'm paying attention now.
Damn it, something's going on here!
I'll say. You just spilled the tea Kasumi so generously made me.
Never mind your excessively lenient arrest.  I've had another two men injured just this morning!
Shitsurei shimashita, Kondo. Might I ask what was going on?
They were monitoring your people as they worked in the engine room. Reprimanding one for slacking, in fact. Then they were scalded by hot gases from a boiler leak!
Oh, dear. I thought I felt a little heartburn.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should lie down, Kasumi. We'll get you patched up.
Everyone's alive and recovering. That's what matters.
Sounds serious. I'll track down whoever was working and get their side.

Fields.DialogueText: No, no, I feel fine now. I've always had trouble with these boilers. It comes and goes.
Perhaps we're all due a refresher on safety measures.
I'm sure they'll corroborate Kondo's officers' story in full.
I know you're behind this, Kami.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Darling?
Is anyone truly behind these accidents?
Accidents? While my men are trying to carry out their duties? Don't make me laugh.
Perhaps you're right, Kondo. An accident implies no one is at fault.
I'm no theologian. But if I had entered the shrine of a god - a living, corporeal god, at that - and met with misfortune... I would be wondering what I'd done to anger the deity in question.
I might even be wondering whether my presence alone was a transgression.
Ah! There's trouble on the horizon. Follow me to the bridge, Kanchou, darling?
This isn't over.
Those military police have been more docile lately.
They should know it's bad luck to offend a goddess.

Fields.MenuText: Don't you think you're going a little mad  with power?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't you think Kondo was going a little mad with power?
So Belles can do things like bend guardrails and burst boilers... on command?
No different from crying on command or dislocating one's own shoulder.
It doesn't hurt?
Depends on what we choose to dislocate. But it's a small price to pay for protecting those who are important to me. As crew and as... something more.
"Darling," eh?
It felt right to say. Does it feel right to hear?
You leave him to me, Kanchou... whatever you may hear.
It's almost like things are back to normal, isn't it?
I've even heard different languages in the mess hall and out on the deck.
People will do what they feel safe doing. The crew are done being afraid because they see tyrants getting theirs.
While our uninvited guests scarcely look funny at them now. They might trip on a stray wire.

Fields.MenuText: I'll be sure not to.
How are they going to report that to the General Staff?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Kanchou! You could never offend me.
The same way anyone reported the existence of Kami in the first place. With surprise and respect.
I can definitely get used to it. Maybe things can stay a little abnormal.
*ALARM*
We'll build a new normal together, Kanchou. Stronger and happier. There's just one more thing that needs to be done.
Kondo.
@BATTLE
Kanchou! A word, if you would?
Kondo. To what do I owe the pleasure?
A final progress report on my assignment here. My men and I have completed our assessment of your patriotic credentials.
Which I can only assume is glowing.
Though it is with deep personal misgivings, I have deemed your conduct -
Ooh! Well, that sounds wonderful, doesn't it, Kanchou? We've passed!
With flying colors. If you'll excuse me, I have matters to attend to in my quarters.
Problem solved.

Fields.MenuText: What did you do to him?
I thought I heard screaming and banging around last night.
Do you think he's going to keep his word?

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing out of the ordinary. He knows as well as anyone that Kami can hurt as well as help, if they are offended.
This ship is my shrine and my body. If it is not properly venerated, it has been known to produce antibodies.
He won't break it so easily with a Kami as with a foreigner. He's a man of honor, however brutal it may be.
I really don't want to know, do I?
We Kami were once hidden from the human world, as you know. It took a crisis to reveal that secret.
Ohayōgozaimasu!
Er... Unimpeachable! Immaculate! A paragon of Imperial service!
What was this?
Merely a bump in the road. Only those who displease me need know more.
I guess that's that sorted. Though there's still one problem.
*ALARM*
Good instinct, Kanchou.
I was actually talking about those extra copies of Madame Bovary we've ended up with.
I'll start a book club or something. The more the merrier!
@BATTLE
It's been a while since we had a proper movie night, hasn't it?
We've accumulated quite the backlog now that those military police goons are no longer holding our mail hostage.
No Morgana movies, eh?
I'm content with that. We could use some down time.

Fields.MenuText: They might be useful for studying the enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: For as long as it takes the enemy to figure out that they're being studied. It's easy to change something by observing it.
The military police aren't going to go away because you scared them, of course.
Not overnight, no. Some of my sisters are almost as zealous as they are. They'll find niches and holes to stick in and fester.
We're all in search of the one thing we're content to die doing, Kanchou. Kondo and I... we're both patriots. But for him, that one thing is wielding power.
Drawing maps. Learning languages. Making the world smaller, no matter how anyone tries to widen the distance between us.
*ALARM*
That's what I've always loved about you, Kanchou. You cut right to the heart of things.
Things like living goddesses.
And demons. With different, more explosive tools, of course.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What did you have in mind?
Something French?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe a little Mansaku Itami. You just don't see his brand of social commentary these days.
Perhaps not a Renoir.
War has a way of letting that happen.
And for you?
The closer we are, the easier it is for everyone to find that one thing.
Looks like Kondo kept his word.
The General Staff got back to us?
Not only have they determined Renoir's escape to be a fluke... they've also formally apologized for impugning the devotion of a Kami of the Fleet.
I suppose that's fairly specific, as their apologies go. I'll take it.
I still don't know what to think of this whole goddess thing.
I doubt they do, either. It's one thing to formally endorse the spirits that live alongside your world. Quite another when those spirits start endorsing you back.
"Undorsing?" Heh. I see what you mean. But it raises all kinds of fascinating questions.

Fields.MenuText: Such as, do you outrank me?

Fields.DialogueText: Technically, I outrank everyone. Short of the Emperor, and to the extent that these things apply, anyway. Think of our dynamic like a monarch selecting a prime minister.
We Kami have always had our own way of communicating with you humans. It hasn't been enough. Now we're speaking up a little louder.
As am I. Walking hand in hand is new to me. I hope it's a new normal.
*ALARM*
Now there are some shrines that could stand a bit of purifying.
@BATTLE
Or undorsing you.

Fields.MenuText: Is this ship really your shrine?
Could a Belle be arrested?

Fields.DialogueText: I am bound to it, and I exercise more or less absolute control over what goes on in here. You could even consider the crew's tasks to be rituals in their own right.
You'd have to catch us first. I'd be lying if I said the thought wasn't... at least a little bit intoxicating.
We're glad you are.
Let's keep the Morganas out of it.
How does this look, Kanchou?
I think it's fine, but some of the crew are raising eyebrows.
Very funny. I'm not talking about us. I'm talking about my interpretation of Shanghai.
Bustling. Lively. Colorful. Exactly the way a port city should be.

Fields.MenuText: You think some colors on a map will really get people to the other side of the world?

Fields.DialogueText: Smaller things have sparked greater.
It's good what you're doing. The world needs people to put it back together after it's come apart.
Even Kondo was trying to do that in his own way. His own brutal way.
So much for a code of honor.
Bushidō is a malleable concept, Kanchou. Especially far from Japan proper.
Your house, your rules, eh?
I'm sure it does. But we are far from Japan proper.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You've certainly found your postwar calling.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope I've found yours as well. Tadataka didn't do his mapping alone.

Fields.MenuText: Are you making military charts or tour guides?

Fields.DialogueText: I started out with the former, but I can't help looking forward to the day they won't be necessary.
Subarashī. The more expressive the map, the more eager the traveler.
I like to think there's room enough in it for all of us. Even gods have responsibilities.
Does bushidō have anything to say about the two of us?
Leave it to a goddess to decide what's proper.
*ALARM*
After some healthy debate, naturally. Join me?
Always.
